jcr:content.jcr:title: Very Best of the Bee Gees

contentheadline.headline: Very Best of the Bee Gees

contentrichtext.text: {{Orphan|date=July 2011}} {{Unreferenced|date=December 2009}} {{mergeto|The Very Best of the Bee Gees|discuss=Talk:The Very Best of the Bee Gees#Merge|date=March 2013}} {{Infobox album <!-- See Wikipedia:WikiProject_Albums --> | Name = Very Best of the Bee Gees | Type = greatest | Artist = [[Bee Gees]] | Cover = | Released = 1990 | Recorded = 1967-1989 | Genre = [[Pop music|Pop]] | Length = | Label = [[Polydor]] | Producer = | Reviews = | Last album = ''[[One (Bee Gees album)|One]]'' <br /> (1989) | This album = ''Very Best of the Bee Gees'' | Next album = ''[[High Civilization]]'' <br /> (1991) }} '''''Very Best of the Bee Gees''''' is an [[album]] by the [[Bee Gees]]. It was released in 1990 by [[record label]] [[Polydor]]. This compilation was assembled from the box set ''[[Tales from the Brothers Gibb: A History in Song]]'' released simultaneously. The new stereo mixes for "World", "Words" and "I've Gotta Get A Message to You" found on the box set are the same mixes used here. The album was only released in Europe and was a big seller in the U.K., charting several times over the years since its release in 1990. ==Track listing== # "New York Mining Disaster 1941" # "To Love Somebody" # "Massachusetts" # "World" # "Words" # "I've Gotta Get a Message to You" # "First of May" # "Don't forget to Remember" # "Saved by the Bell" # "Run to Me" # "Jive Talkin'" # "Nights on Broadway" # "You Should be Dancing" # "How Deep is Your Love" # "More than a Woman" # "Stayin Alive" # "Night Fever" # "Too Much Heaven" # "Tragedy" # "You Win Again" # "Ordinary Lives" {{DEFAULTSORT:Very Best Of The Bee Gees}} [[Category:1990 greatest hits albums]] [[Category:Bee Gees albums]] {{1990s-compilation-album-stub}}
